Poor Management
Corporate politics
Lack of career development and/or opportunities for promotion
Lacked work life balance

pros: great upper management who cares about their employees
cons: lack of advancement opportunities for lower level employees

job_title: Heavy Equipment Operator in Birmingham, AL
pros: Good experience to use for future jobs
cons: Horrible boss, Also bad management

pros: You get paid decent money
cons: have to work long hours

pros: Friendly work environment, good hours
cons: Work area can be dull

pros:
It is a great internship and full time position to get you started into the industry. I heard benefits are great, but I don't know myself because I didn't have any due to my internship position.
A lot of hands on opportunity to develop lab skills if working in quality control. Pay is descent based in the standards on the area. 
Great training and amazing crew that is willing to share their knowledge with you to learn and help out.
Overall great opportunity to gain new skills and grow your network.
cons:
Not many opportunities for growing in the company, which is dissapointing after putting a lot of work and training on you, one may believe that the company invest in the individual to provide more opportunitites within the company. 
Internship experience wish would have been more management exposure as well, for The intern to understand the role of a technician and so of a supervisor or manager role.

pros: People, life, stuff you get to see
cons: Upper management, upper management, upper management

pros: Good pay, lots of over time
cons: Crappy hours, have to call in every evening

job_title: I Was Told I Was Just A Worker, That Was A Slap In the Face
pros: Relaxed atmosphere.  Alright pay.  Absolutely no fear of getting fired, I'm not kidding, it's ridiculous to see what I've seen some people do.  As long as your manager thinks you wont rat him out to anyone, your golden.
cons: I have to question who they choose to become managers.  Hard work and know how, only makes other less secure coworkers try to make you look bad.  And I'm not just saying that out of anger, I've had it done to me, and I've see it done to others.  They preach safety, but then your manager will try to make you do things that are dangerous or illegal, then your the jerk when you refuse.  I just wanted a job where I can get promoted and promotions due to merritt, not just dumb luck, or sucking up to undeserving managers,  so I quit, and moved, with no house nor job.  I then landed one within weeks and make more money, more benefits, more happy.

review_title: Vulcan is dropping like a rock
pros:
- Good benefits
- Excellent corporate office facility and most division office facilities
- Freedom at the division level
- Many division positions have company provided vehicles
- Sales jobs are cream puff jobs for mediocre performers
- Great place to work if you just want to "get by"
cons:
- There is virtually no senior leadership or vision for the company
- Working at the Corporate Office requires the patience of Job due to having to convince 9 divisions to do whatever needs to be done
- Division offices are highly political
- Poorly timed acquisition that was funded by a huge amount of debt significantly weakened the viability of this company
- Jobs cuts are becoming the "new normal" but rarely target division or corporate managers, directors or executives
- Limited prospects for growth - no bonuses paid in 4 years with no end in sight
- Executives have an "elite" mentality, reward themselves with high compensation/options while remaining largely uninvolved in the business

pros: Friendly co-workers, many great people that are excellent at their jobs, 401K match is good after you have been with the company while. Corporate headquarters is more progressive than the divisions. The company was down during the recession, but now I expect the company to recover and have strong growth, despite the CEO, Don James, because of the strength of others.
cons: Many people accepted salaries that were sometimes far below the standard, with the understanding that long-term benefits made up for those, and now those long-term benefits like pension and low-cost insurance have disappeared. People often feel pressured not to take sick days. The company seemed very employee centered with a small company feel before the Florida Rock acquisition, but after, it felt like working for a large corporation headed the wrong direction.

review_title: Not What It Used To Be
pros: Vulcan has an above average benefits package, and the company is stable with few layoffs.  They have made strides in making the workplace more fair towards women and minorities.  They match charitable contributions, and the rank-and-file employees are very loyal and dedicated to the company, particularly the ones that have been there for many years.
cons: Benefits are being quickly changed to make them just average, rather than above average.  HR seems to spend a lot of time finding ways to keep salaries down.  If a female employee doesn't play by the right 'Southern Belle' rules, she may as well leave, because there will be no promotions or decent raises.  Most importantly, bad middle managers are protected at the expense of their direct reports.  Upper management seems to be more concerned with how things look, than how they actually are.

review_title: Good money if you can put up with lots of BS
pros:
Great benefits
Good people
Big company so there are opportunities to relocate
cons:
Negative company culture. The culture encourages people to point fingers when mistakes are made, pass the buck, and put profits over people

Poor management. Micromanage and don't do the work to allow their employees to be successful at the job. It starts at the very top and the negative effects seep all the way to the quarry level. 

If it's broke, apologize but never fix the problem

Vulcan markets itself as an industry leader so they rush to make changes with no preparation, leaving employees and customers frustrated.

review_title: Used to be a good place to work
pros:
Good benefits package
Good lower level employees
Good compensation (salary)
cons:
Promotions from within, especially women, is sorely lacking.
Good ole' boy system still a major factor in day to day business.
Upper and lower management decisions remain very secretive affecting day to day operations particularly for people who aspire to climb the "corporate ladder". 
Overworked lower level employees, especially since round two of lay-offs. 
Sales staff remains allowed to run amok and account to no one for their time or dealings.

review_title: New managers are not always what they seem...
pros: Some managers lead by example and encourage their employees to grow, some managers may not be leaders, but do a great job at being fair and equitable to all they manage.
cons: Some management is only focused on their own advancement. use whatever means to move forward, including stepping on their own people and holding them back. Women are limited in their advancement unless you are in the "minority" group, so they have their token diversity.

review_title: Good stable company.  Great if you aren't real ambitious.
pros: Good benefits and good working conditions.    They are very understanding about personal/medical situations that might affect attendance.   The company is very conservative, but they don't make a lot of mistakes, either.  Acquisitions, changes in business are well thought out.
cons: It is had to advance one's career at Vulcan,  There is a great deal of nepotism in management, and lots of poor mid-level managers.  If you don't get a promotion early in your career you probably won't get one at all.  One particular department was so bad they couldn't fill jobs internally.  Yet the manager was allowed to sustain a hostile work environment despite repeated complaints from subordinates.

review_title: The worst job I have ever had. Hate it.
pros: A paycheck...that comes once a month unfortunately.
cons: Liberty Park location: This is the worst company I have ever worked for. Management talks to their employees like they are nothing. And other management excuses it as "just the way the person is." Training is minimal, and they expect you to psychically know what to do. The company hasn't made a profit in years. They expect you to work super long hours, and you almost feel guilty for getting off on time. Again the worst company I have ever worked for. I am thankful to no longer be there. As well, the company is located near woods, so there are constantly spiders and other bugs crawling around the building. Cafeteria is very expensive. No sick time. (HR lied to me about that.) Restrooms don't have hot water. I went from the white house to the out house when I took a job at Vulcan, literally. I'm now back at the white house :)

job_title: Don’t Work for This Company If Your A Minority You Won’t BE Happy
pros:
-Good sincere people working at the lower levels of the company ie. truckers, dispatch team etc.
- good medical benefits
cons:
- huge good old boy network
- nepotism upper execs hire family members for key roles when not qualified and move up quick
- very non diverse
- very few minorities at this company especially in upper mgt
- no communication 
- no training
- no continuing education
- no learning
- Many clicks within organization
- upper mgt is not qualified and act privileged

review_title: Vulcan is a great place to work
pros: Vulcan is a good, solid company with great benefits and great employees. With the recent promotion of Tom Hill to CEO, we now have a great forward vision that was missing in the past. With the economy picking up, Vulcan is poised to do great things in the future.
cons: Some upper management positions are filled with the wrong people just because they've been with the company a long time. In my opinion, positions should be filled with the most qualified people and not filled with people due to their longevity with the company.

review_title: Long line of people waiting on promotions that are mostly based on tenure rather that merit.
pros: Great benefits. The senior management is great, but the mid level management is somewhat lacking. Vulcan is a great place to start a career, but if you desire advancement, you will have to look elsewhere if you have less than 8-10 years experience.
cons: It is a great place to work, but there are a lot of old ideas still in place and a resistance to change anything that effects the middle management old guard's way of doing business.

pros: The market and need will exist more than most for this industry.  If you are adept in playing the game of changing loyalties within the organization, you will be fine working here.
cons:
Need to truly watch your back and not share any personal opinions with anyone no matter how confident you feel in your business relationship with them.  You see and read about this type of work environment in the media but to actually work in it is a truly eye opening experience and makes one really appreciate no longer working there.  What is billed as an "open communication" environment should be revised to an "Open communication" environment as long as you have nothing negative to say.  

This is not an organization of "one goal, one vision" but rather a test of survival.  Tread lightly and good luck.

job_title: Quality Control Technician in Brownwood, TX
pros: The salary, and benefits, are good.
cons: Poor area management, poor supervisors, vindictive atmosphere

job_title: Mobile Maintenance in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great Benefits
Competitive Hourly Pay
Excellent Safety Culture
Friendly Coworkers
Overtime 
Optional Weekend Work
cons:
Underqualified Supervisors
Lack of People Skills from Management
Mentality of “not my job” from individuals.
Lack of initiative to help other employees.

review_title: Management has their heads in the sand!
pros: Benefits or what is left of them. They need to realize the new people they hire because they have a degree are probably not the best choice...look at the ones you trained that gave their all for you. Then you shoved them right out in the cold. How is the degreed idiot working for you doing? Oh they couldn't handle the job and you had to let them go...
cons: If you are male you can go far, if female try another company.

review_title: A formerly great company, on the decline
pros: Financially stable company with a lot of great employees throughout the country.
cons: Used to feel like a family, where employees were truly valued.  Employees at all levels are now treated as expendable pieces of the "machine" that the business functions as.  "Do as I say, not as I do" attitude of a lot of mid-level and upper-level management.

review_title: Decent company to work for, but there is a copious amount of room for improvement.
pros: The benefits are good. Most of the people are great to work with. I was able to get task trained on several pieces of heavy equipment and I also got my CDL through the company.
cons: Mid-level management lacks interpersonal communication skills, leadership qualities. Several benefits discussed during interview were pulled off the table at a later date (tuition reimbursement, sick days). Not very many opportunities to move up.

job_title: Heat Treat Operator in Pelham, AL
pros: Great boss and wonderful co-workers plus GREAT pay
cons: Hot, I worked in heat treat.. in 1 year I climbed the social hiarchys ladder to one of the 6 best jobs. Mostly every worker was less than happy I was given the job..But I missed no days ,NEVER LATE, Always had a side job going

review_title: OK for a job, but not a career
pros:
Weekends off, most of the time
Not a micromanaging atmosphere
cons:
Schedule changes a lot on short notice(like the day before)
Pay is below other similar industries in the area
Supervisors are in place due to "Good Ol Boy" system and are very much lacking.
No extra compensation for cross training and learning other areas.

review_title: A great company but slowly going down hill
pros: The employees at Vulcan are the best in the industry.  Job title really doesn't matter, everyone is willing to do whatever they can to get the job done.
cons: The company has forgotten that the employees is what made this company successful. We have been loosing benefits over the years: health club reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, health care plan benefits declining but cost increasing.  And the most recent, loss of pension.

review_title: Vulcan's Good Reputation Has Went Down The Drain
pros: Decent pay, vacation and holiday pay. The company has scholarship programs and supports local schools. Supports Holy Family High School and allows students to intern with Vulcan, has employee tuition reimbursement (though this has stopped for new employees).
cons: Mid level management treats employees in a horrible manner. Employees can report problems to HR or upper management but ultimately nothing is done to resolve the problem. One department has had many employees "laid off" or "let go" but none of them have been replaced. Most departments are operating with a skeleton crew in which each employee is doing several different tasks or taking on the combined work that would have once belonged to two or more other employees. The employees are not being compensated or promoted. Vulcan's insurance plan was once excellent and a major reason why people would want to work for them, however, the benefits get worse each year while the price steadily increases. Also, you can forget about promotions in the company. Even if you obtain a degree you will be told that you do not have the experience to move into a position. The workforce has been greatly reduced and employees are taking on more responsibilities and, in some cases, doing the work that once belonged to 2 or 3 employees. The work has to be done but management becomes angry if the overtime budget is exceeded. Also, while Vulcan pays for employees to have short term disability (sick time is taken out of this) many managers become irate if employees take sick time. This appears to be due to reduced workforce as work quickly piles up because employees have no one to help take on their workload when they are absent. While employees cannot be reprimanded for taking FMLA I know of several employees who have had snide remarks made toward them for taking it (i.e. a coworker was talked down to for having to extend her FMLA due to complications from childbirth)

pros: Great if you are a conservative straight white male. You will be paid more and promoted over your more qualified female counterparts.
cons: They preach diversity and inclusion and then do the opposite. If you are a woman, minority or identify with LGBTQ you will not make it far in this company.  They overwork the good employees and run them into the ground while the bad employees skate by.

review_title: Do you want to keep your CDL? if so, don't apply here. you will violate FMSCA everyday.
pros:
Got experience.
Learned about concrete and now I know how to make a concrete patio in my backyard
cons:
Horrible company to work for.
They preach never to break Federal and DOT law by not violating under any circumstances, even if that means rejecting a load if you're close to 15 hours.. Yet, if you reject the load, you get either fired, reprimanded, or retaliated against by dispatch sending you to the worse job and high possibility of getting in to an accident.  Trust me, I know.
They retaliate against employees for trying to sticking up for yourself: when your right, yet management blames you so they don't have to take the heat.
Horrible working conditions.  The Ready Mix trucks they own are unsafe and dangerous - trucks flip over taking left and turns going 5 MPH, tires constantly blow on highways while fully loaded, dispatch will "forget" about you when your broken down with an expensive load and tell you a mechanic is on the way, but yet he has no idea your broken down.  So when that load goes bad, you tell your manager you called dispatch for a mechanic, dispatch will cover there own job and lie which leads to you getting fired.
Federal Law says trucks cannot be hauling more than 5 yards on the Interstates Highways, well, they carry 9.5-10, so the drivers are taking the loads bellieving it's okay, when it's actually against the law (they won't tell you that, but with my recent meeting with The Department of Transportation, they said it is "highly illegal and dangerous".
You work the worst hours possibly.  15+ hour days, with a "mandatory" 8 hour break in between shifts) yet they won't obey that.  You'll come in at 1a.m, work until 5 or 6 p.m (again, breaking 15 hours) then clock out and you find out your start time the next day is at 12a.m  (6-7 hour break) and at the end of the year they will tell you that your load count needs to increase while giving you a $.10 raise while management is getting massive bonuses and raises.
Favortism is to the point that Batchman, and dispatch will try very hard to get you transferred to another division, or drive you out of the job just so their favorites don't have to take the last load or violate..
HR is goody-goody with management.  I filed a grievence asin't my manager for trying to load me up at 14 hours and 54 minutes to go to a job 25 miles away, at 5pm in the afternoon, with the only way to get there is to go on the interstate.  When I expressed me concern about violating he told me to take it and "i'll make an accepetion for the FMSCA law" (How can you do that for a law??) anyways, i was about to back my truck up to the plant to get loaded because if didn't then i'd be fired.  So even though I didn't want too, I got in my truck but heard over the radio from my back up batchman (plant operator)  not to back up the plant.  It turns out that dispatch voided my ticket after being grilled by my back up plant operator that I'd violate...  So they told me to wash out, park my truck and go home..  Well, I ended up getting written up for "rejecting" that load, when I NEVER DID!  i explained my part of the story about how dispatch told me to wash out.. Well he tells me that he made his decision and that dispatch said I rejected the load.. When I had 8 witnesses telling my manager that it didn't happen like that.. I still got written up.  
The next Monday I go in to work with wires hanging out the back of a truck (mine was in the shop), the back lights didn't work, there was a hole in the hopper that would blow cement powder over cars following me, and 2 tires were flat.  After my PTi I deemed the truck unsafe to drive.  I tell my Plant Operator, and he tells me that if i didn't take the truck and get loads out, he will contact my manager.  In a normal company, that'd be okay, i'd say "go for it the truck is broken", yet at VMC, management will side with the batchman and completely disregard the driver.  Well i refused to drive it and he called my manager and he suspended me for "slashing the tires and pulling the wires out myself" when that was impossible, I had people around me while I was doing my PTI and they told my manager that i didn't do it and they were with me... he still suspended me and blamed me while laughing saying "i should have taken the truck".
I filed a Grievence and when I went to a mediation (with my manager present) The HR guy asked me why I was in this office with him when I haven't had any infractions, write ups (until 2 weeks before)  and had been a "perfect employee".. I explained my situation and really focused on the 15 hour violation and how it's against the law and even though we are told not to violate, but when it comes down to it we are written up or fired.  The HR guy said "well that is a grey area in this company that will always exist.  Management has to make that decision everyday, but rest assured, if ANYTHING happens, it falls on the manager"
Well that's false, 'cause drivers have been forced to take loads after 15 hours, and something always happens, whether it be an accident or whatever, but when the cop asks why your over 15 hours and you tell him you were told by the manager it was okay.. The cop explains to you every time, that if you are caught behind the wheel of a commercial vehicle after 15 hours, it is 100% your fault because you are considered fatigued.  Also,  when your manager arrives and the cop asks if he gave permission to take the load, the manager covers his job and says something along the lines of "we have a policy that states that driver should know when they are going to violate and communicate that to management, I never recieved a call from this driver"  

it's absolutely disgusting.

P.S.  If your single, it works, if you have a family or baby due soon, don't expect to get off for the baby being born, a driver as on stand by at the end of the day, when he got a call from his wife's friend asking where he was at, they were at the hospital because his wife was in the middle of labor and she called his manager to tell him that (drivers aren't allowed to have cell phones in trucks)  they wrre on the way to the hospital an hour ago.  Well the manager didn't tell the driver, didn't get on the radio to inform him of his daughter being born, or even call the Plant Operator to tell him because the driver had been at the plant for 4 hours on stand by doing nothing but sitting in his truck..  The driver responded to her wife's friend that nobody told him anything..  When he confronted the manager, the manager said he never got a phone call from anybody.  I was right by the driver when all this happened.  if you have a family and request off to spend time with them on a saturday, they won't let you because it's a work day.

pros: Family oriented.   If sick, court, funeral etc and  you have documentation no points accrued.
cons: Unsafe work place.  Forklift drivers are not trained properly.  Accidents are not reported by management.  Lazy people in management.  Have other people doing their work because they are too lazy to do it themselves.  Associates reaps of alcohol and marijuana .  Dirty work areas.  Associates use profanity around supervisors and nothing is done about it.i Supervisors dating associates so that associate @ have special privileges such as do absolutely nothing.  It is a mess.

review_title: Good family feel. Great leadership at the Division level. Corporate is lost.
pros: Great support structure and plenty of opportunity. Lots of growth. They are always looking at acquisitions. A large amount of retirements happening allowing you to move around if you wish.
cons: Corporate not being utilized as a tool. Instead as a hindrance. Corporate out of touch. Dirty environment. Quarries are dusty and hot. Very much exposed to the elements.

review_title: This company has no love for it's Hourly Employees, all they care about is putting a lot of money in their pockets.
pros: It’s just a job now, I wish I could say something good about it but I don’t want to tell you a lie. Hourly pay scale is too low, benefits are going so high in 2013 that it’s going to be a finical burden just to pay the premiums, co-pays are already  so high that the average hourly worker can’t use it and in 2013 they are going higher, some of the people will have to work in extreme pain do to medical problems, which in turn will affect productivity, but they will have no choice, because they have to buy gas to get to work and be able to put food on the table and pay other bills just to live. So if you don’t owe for anything, and you live with your parents or someone else and don’t have a family of your own, then this may be a good place for you to work as long as you don’t have any aspiration to make good money or move up in the company.
cons: When I first started working for this Company I had high expectations of learning to do a lot of different jobs, so that I would be a better asset for the Company  and could make more money. But after learning to do numerous jobs I got no raise in pay, in fact, I learned that I was not even being paid the same as someone who could do only one of the jobs that I could do. Local Management and supervisors don’t seem to have a clue as to what they are doing,  as long as they look good to the upper Management that’s all they care about, they could care less about those out here doing the actual work. They have the buddy program here, that is as long as they like you and you are willing to kiss their backsides then you will do good here.

pros: The pay is competitive . They offer a good benefits package. They also do a 401K match which is better than most companies. Company wide everybody receives boot allowance and safety equipment.
cons: The work schedule is unpredictable. There is NO opportunity for advancement within the company. Work/Life balance does not exist. Management is out of Sync. Operates under the good ole' boy system.

review_title: Not the company I thought “it “ was, at all.
job_title: Ready Mix Driver in Baltimore, MD
pros: Safety! new trucks, and health benefits
cons: Communication is poor, what’s said and what is actually done doesn’t match, favoritism is a all time high, how trucks are ran waste more time than actually saves time and fuel. Only certain drivers are held to “standard “ while others get away with things what would get another employee suspended or fired. Very disappointed overall, genuinely want the company to be successful because in return we all will be successful. But doesn’t seem to be the right fit for me and several of my fellow coworkers.

pros: Provides good benefits to employees, such as 401K with matching, health, dental and vision; disability, life.
cons: They do not consistently promote from within.  Lately they have been going outside the company, without giving current employees an opportunity. Some management plays by their own rules.

pros: The company pays pretty good. You make your money from the overtime hours. Very established company. The company has been around for many years
cons: You have to work every day even when you are sick because there is no one to take your place. When the customers want to work late or weekend you must work them.

pros: prety good benefits an not bad pay
cons: florida rock was sold to vulcan a couple of years ago an we still have the rock management.They do not listen to employees an favortism is unbelievable.Way to heavy in management lots of wasted money.

pros: Good benefits and 401k plan, money is great
cons: Some plants are great some plants are horrible, it's a watch your back atmosphere. Lots of people with years of experience and new people are targets. And mentioning HR is painting a target on your back!

pros: Being outside everyday. You are not working on the same thing everyday as a welder. Vulcan is good about safety.
cons: Some of the down sides are the heat in the summer and the cold in the winter. The work can be very physical and rough on your body if you don’t watch it.

review_title: I guess were a step above China, safety wise but the buddy system," that doesn't exist" seems to be based on what church
pros: A check, small pension, insurance, good part time job, good safety bonus if your working
cons: Your number to company, corpate eyes, not plant mangers and down. Budgetcost companymore moneymake $ look goodpaper, fixed$10orwait nextmonthcost $100.

review_title: If you read one review make sure its this one!!!!!!
pros: The benefits are the only thing that made me punch in on the time clock. Pay was descent but that type of work it could have been a little more. Working here did make me realize what job I had before I was at vulcan and made and how they are better things out there
cons: Shew where do I start?!?!?!?!?!?!?!? The most important one that got to me was that "upper management" had no respect for the men. I hired in as general support which consisted of plant clean up, maintenance, inspecting rollers, belts pulleys etc etc. I have a background of welding which i was told there would be welding involved in this job, yeah sounded great to me. The catch was I would do 90% of the welding and continued not to get welders pay. There is no room for improvement like "upper management" talks about. Only way to move up was to take some college which i have. I once even asked about going back to school to help me move up with the company. That went in one ear and out the other with the bosses. They're really not that concerned about the working man. Scared to death of MSHA and getting wrote up. During the winter months you better hope your wife has a good job because if it snows, rains or the temp drops below freezing you was lucky if you got to work. They are so old school it isnt funny its a shame. The tools they supply you with is awful. Reminds me very much of a Ma and Pa shop. Oh and not to mention I worked with men that had 25+ years there and there salary was only 38k to 40k. Upper management really needs to open there eyes and understand that its the men doing the manual labor work while supervisors push a pencil and if it wasnt for the men there paycheck wouldnt be there>

review_title: A driving force in the world of  aggregate.
pros: Willing to cross train and invest in their employees.  Will do what they can to keep everyone on all year.
cons: Big company find to include all major decisions are made at corporate level without input from local leadership. Sometimes picking up the slack as the younger employees.

job_title: Mobile Maintenance in San Diego, CA
pros: Great pay and benefits. Always busy.
cons: Hope you enjoy a 7 day work week

pros: This is a well positioned and stable company.  Compensation is fair and benefits are good.
cons: Culture has become degraded.  It’s not even about the P&L.  It’s who’s team you are on.   Your accomplishments don’t matter!  Everyone has a target on their back... from middle management to the executive level!!!

pros: Great company with great leadership... really like the direction the company is headed.  Good benefits and competitive salaries.
cons: No cons to report.  Management team in place will continue to guide the company toward greater market share and profitability

review_title: Good people that work with you especially if you have family issues.
job_title: Heavy Equipment Operator Level IV in San Antonio, TX
pros: A good place to work if you are a labor kind of person. Plus they will train you in many jobs. Very respectable Managers that work with you to get the job done.
cons: You don't always do the job you were hired for.

job_title: District Sales Manager in Flowery Branch, GA
pros: Excellent business culture, team work and support.  Great Benefits in sales including entertaining customers, company car, etc.
cons: Tend to be on the lower end of the pay scale.  Very slow upward progression because very few people leave the company

pros: Enjoyable summer working and learning basics in quality control, plant maintenance and materials handling.
cons: I wouldn't consider the experience as an internship, but more as general support work. I would've enjoyed being asked to do some more challenging tasks and getting more one on one work.

pros: Great insurance and benefits program.  They have a diversified structure so there is something for everyone. Steady and dependable job
cons: Not much chance for advancement unless you are in good with management.  Annual pay raises last 20 years are 2 1/2% across the board. Hours and number of days a week could change anytime. You are expected to work it with little or no notice

review_title: A company that has lost its direction
pros:
Don't have to be terribly smart to stay employed.
Some co-workers do actually care about you.
Used to be a very secure and stable company.
cons:
Inefficient practices and non-profit producing departments kept around due to personal loyalties and not sound business decisions.
Severely incompetent people in positions of authority and responsible for strategic planning.

review_title: Overall it was a great working and learning environment.
job_title: Human Resources Administrator in Glendale, CA
pros: Great Executive staff and HR Department. People really enjoy and know their job. Dedication is great.
cons: Evidence of double-standards and some managers get away with things that others may be terminated for. In the past some people have received promotions without truly earning it. Due to the economy, business has slowed down significantly.

pros: Management team is dedicated and customer focused.  Good working environment with knowledgeable colleagues.  Benefits are fair and equitable.
cons: Continued margin pressures  due to cyclical nature of the business have resulted in cost cutting measures and loss of excellent employees.

pros:
They have good benefits such as vacation, sick days, swing holidays, cheap insurance, 401k.
The pay is somewhat competetive.
cons: Managment is poor. Not in field enough. Not many raises. Work far from home sometimes.

pros: Vulcan Materials Company is bar none a world class sales organization. VMC treats every employee with respect and treats them like family. Everyone is giving the same opportunity to grown regardless of where you enter the company.
cons: My only con thus far would be the office building in which we operate from. It is slightly dated and could use major renovations.

pros: Convenient, stable employer who has adapted well to the downturn in the economy.
cons: Employees have largely been asked to carry the burden of the downturn with additional responsibilities, people leaving are not replaced and salaries are flat.

review_title: Good pay. But saw a few good men fired for basically no reason.
pros: Pay was good. Good training and benefits. Hard work pays off. Would promote from within while I was there.
cons: Long hours. Very very dirty environment. Short turn around from being off and having to come back to work. Crazy

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great equipment. Great management. Plenty of hours. We use a variety of heavy equipment to mine rock. We then process the rock for sale.
cons: We tend to work long hours, twelve to fourteen hours a day. Low rate of hourly pay is offset by the long hours and overtime pay.

pros: It was a fun place to work. The pay wasn't the greatest but I enjoyed the job.
cons: I was alone most of the time with a lot of cash so that was something I didn't care for.

review_title: Vulcan can be a great place to work
